dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A garbage truck roars by and... Simon Grim hangs from the back of it. He is a shy, skinny and terrified-looking guy around thirty years old. The truck rumbles to a halt and Simon climbs down off it go punch out at the time clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. He comes walking up a small alley and sits to drink his b He begins to relax. This is his quality private time. Then he hears something and looks up. He peeks up over the edge of some junked kitchen applianc and sees... Two teenage kids -- Warren and Amy -- smoking crack and h sex. Simon looks on, intrigued, as Warren smokes, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Amy) You want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy takes the pipe and smokes as he feels her up. Simon is fascinated. He drinks and looks on as... Amy grins up foolishly at Warren and lowers the pipe. The boy undoes his belt and hikes up the girl's skirt. Simon can't believe this. He looks around to see if the c is clear, then returns just in time to see... Warren takes Amy by the waist and enter her. The pipe falls from the young girl's hand. Warren throws his head back and grinds himself into her. Simon's mouth falls open in awe. But Amy tosses her head back to the side and sees... The amazed garbage man; caught. Amy starts screaming insanely. Simon runs for his life. Amy and Warren throw rocks and bottles at him as they cha him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon runs up and throws open the screen door. He stands  there in the doorway catching his breath. His sister, Fay, is at the kitchen table watching a small portable TV while their mother, Mary, sits a few feet awa in the living-room watching another TV tuned to a differe channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simon) Where the hell have you been? (to Mary) Mom, come on and eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed) Then why'd I cook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is a manic-depressive, still in her bathrobe at six the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you cooked! I don't  know why you bother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay holds her head in her hands and sighs. She glares at brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down and eat, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon sits at the table and Fay slams down before him a b of some sort of gruel. He hesitates, then lifts his spoon Supper is horrible and he screws up his face in disgust. gives him a sideways glance and he leans back down over t bowl and eats some more. Pushing the bowl away gently, he reaches out for the cont of milk on the table and drinks straight from it. He suddenly jumps back and spits out sour milk all over t table. The container drops to the floor and thick globs o cheese roll out. He stands back against the fridge, holding his stomach  while... Fay and Mary look on in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon crosses the lawn and sits on the curb outside his h He stares at the ground before him as he holds his stomac and spits, sickened. He looks up, though, and sees... A little seven-year-old girl -- Pearl age seven -- standi there in the street watching him. Simon tries to smile at her. But she throws a rock at him and hits him in the head. He falls forward, hurt, as the little girl runs away. Low his hand, he sees he's bleeding. Desperate, lonely and il he drags his bloodied fingers across the coarse pavement. Fay slams out of the side door of the house in a tight-fi dress and stands on the lawn, applying lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I wanna get fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay snaps shut her compact, straightens her skirt and sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon loses track of what he is hearing and relaxes. He l back at his sister. Fay fluffs out her hair and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon watches her go, but is still drawn to something he  seems to hear up the street in the other direction. He co his head, sits perfectly still and listens. He hears it now. We do, too. Footsteps. Big ones. Like a  giant somewhere in the distance. The neighborhood tremble Titles begin. Simon tries to figure out where it's coming from; the sky the house, the highway at the end of his block... Finally he focuses on... The blacktop right before him, smeared with his own blood Music starts. He kneels out slowly into the street and stares at the  pavement. He stretches out his hand and places it flat on the road. The pounding is louder now, becoming the beat o the music over the scene. Simon lowers his face to the pavement, closes his eyes an Puts his ear right down against the road. He hears... The steady tread of somebody very much larger than life. Kneeling forward, with his ear to the ground, Simon opens his eyes and sees... A man approaching. The music swells up full. Simon lifts his head slowly from the road, looking off in wonder at... This stranger coming towards him; an oddly handsome freak striding over the crest of the distant intersection with windswept mane, two over-stuffed suitcases and a crumpled tie fluttering back over his broad but crooked shoulders. Simon rises till he's kneeling up straight in the road. Henry Fool finally reaches him and stops. Titles finish. Simon says nothing and watches as Henry looks off at the  house. Satisfied, but wary, Henry Fool looks around the neighbor and then down at Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up off your knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the suitcases down in front of Simon and walks towards his new home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry comes around behind the house and finds the door to his basement apartment. He approaches. Simon follows, car the suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. The door is wrenched open and Henry is hit square in the by a decade of dank airless gloom. He coughs. Entering, he finds a few old wooden chairs littering the  main room. He inspects the old wood stove, then takes a c and smashes it. He tosses the wood in the stove. Simon looks on, amazed. Henry lights a fire with unusuall quick results, then stands back and looks at Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you gotta go to get a six-pack  of beer around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a convenience store with a number of tables at wh to eat donuts. Warren is shoplifting while Amy terrorizes Gnoc Deng, the Vietnamese cashier, who stares out at them from behind th safety of the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) She's mute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't -- you know -- talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy looks back at Gnoc, snarls, then follows the cashier' gaze to the door. Simon enters. Clutching Henry's cash, he stops dead in hi tracks when he sees... Warren and Amy. He steps forward and approaches the beer cooler. Warren and Amy hover around, just out of reach, like a co of vampires. Dragging a six-pack out of the cooler, Simon crosses to t counter. Warren and Amy hang back, silent and threatening Gnoc rings up the purchase and glances over at... Amy, staring a hole into the side of Simon's skull. Gnoc hands Simon back his change and he makes for the doo but... Warren shoves himself between it and Simon. Simon freezes. Warren is expressionless. Simon looks back Amy. She turns away, reaches up under her skirt, jerks do her panties, then leans forward on to the counter. Leerin back over her shoulder, she hisses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is nonplussed. Gnoc presses a button on the wall that sets... A red light flashing above the stockroom door. Warren grabs Simon by the neck and drags him over to Amy' bare behind. Amy laughs as Simon is forced to his knees a has his face shoved up right into the crack of her ass. But then... Simon throws up all over her. Warren falls back in disgust. Gnoc covers her face with her hands. Amy looks around at herself, realizes, and starts screami bloody murder. Simon falls back on to the floor, clutching his stomach, Amy staggers around with her vomit-strewn underwear down  around her ankles. Then Gnoc's father, Mr Deng, appears at the stockroom doo holding a shovel and ready to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) Oh, shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deng comes running at them and Warren drags Amy from t store. Simon crawls out of the way as the old man throws  open the door to the parking lot and screams at the retre delinquents...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Vietnamese) Stay the hell out of my store, you  good-for-nothing punks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having scared them off, he comes back in and starts screa at Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this! What's going on here?  Simon, get up off the floor! Is this  beer paid for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Simon splashes water over his face at the kitchen sink, t watches as Henry unpacks one of his suitcases. It is fill with dozens of old, worn notebooks. Henry stacks them on mantelpiece over the fireplace; the fire is now crackling and bright. Simon steps over and looks at... The name tag on the other suitcase: 'Henry Fool'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Centuries ago it had an 'e' at the  end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks over and sees... Henry's silhouette against the fire. He steps forward int the light and grabs a beer from the six-pack on the floor He hands one to Simon. Simon takes it and stares at it a moment before raising h eyes to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winks at Simon, then struts around the room, hugely  impressed with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go where I will and I do what I  must. (stops, drinks) That's why I'm in trouble. I'm sort've  what you might call... 'in exile'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping) An honest man is always in trouble,  Simon. Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon comes away from the fire, watching him carefully. H stands in a dim corner across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry pauses, looks aside, drinks, then grins demoniacall He steps forward and comes face to face with Simon. He li his finger and points to... Simon's name stitched upon the breast of his work shirt. Realizing this, Simon moves off and thinks. Henry throws more wood on the fire, glancing back over hi shoulder, laughing mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping him) I am not retarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses) Well... I'll take your word for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) People. I mean. They think. You know.  Because.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to articulate what he thinks he feels but winds gesticulating curiously with his hands. This finally diss into a dumb stare into empty space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks at him. Henry stands and grabs a notebook fro off the mantelpiece. He tears out a few pages and shoves  them in his pocket. He hands the now fresh writing tablet Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take this. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He searches his pockets and finds a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this. Keep them with you at all  times. You ever feel like you got  something to say and you can't get  it out, stop and write it down. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon hesitates, then accepts the gifts. Henry goes for  another beer while his new friend studies the dozens of  notebooks on the mantelpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly, returning) This? This is my life's work. My  memoirs. My 'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry drinks and looks down into the raging fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I've been bad. Repeatedly. (shrugs and steps  away) But why brag? The details of my  exploits are only a pretext for a  far more expansive consideration of  general truths. (contemplating the  notebooks) What is this? It's a philosophy. A  poetics. A politics, if you will. A  literature of protest. A novel of  ideas. A pornographic magazine of  truly comic-book proportions. It is,  in the end, whatever the hell I want  it to be. And when I'm through with  it, it's gunna blow a hole this wide  straight through the world's own  idea of itself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smokes. Simon is impressed. They hear a bottle smash  outside in the street and Henry goes to the window. They' throwing bottles at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing down his  cigarette) Come on, let's go break their arms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stops. Simon looks away and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses) If I'm quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is ashamed of himself. Henry sees this and settles down. He considers his new fr with genuine care as he gets himself a new cigarette. He  lights up, thinks, then grabs another chair and sits clos by Simon. They sit there in silence a while, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once. I forget where I was. Central  America maybe. Somewhere hot. Stupid  job. Bad pay. Dangerous location and  water so foul the natives wouldn't  even piss in it. This crowd of drunken  motherfuckers hired by the local  drug cartel shows up at my hotel  room and threatens to tear me limb  from limb. And I say, listen, hombres,  OK, you've got me outnumbered four  to one and you're gunna kill me here  tonight and not a soul in this dimly  lit world is ever gunna notice I'm  gone. Fine. But one of you... one of  you... one of you is gunna have his  eye torn out. Period. Silence. I  repeat myself. One of you poor,  underpaid jerks is gunna have an eye  ripped out of its socket. I promise.  It's a small thing, perhaps, all  things considered. But I will succeed.  Because it's the only thing I have  left to do in this world. So why  don't you just take a good look at  one another one last time and think  it over for a few minutes more. (smokes, waits) They sober up a little, look at their  shoes in confusion, then step out  into the hall to talk among  themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stares into the flames and falls silent. Simon is  riveted. He leans forward, on the edge of his seat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking) Well, here I am, still, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Simon climbs the stairs and stops when he hears raunchy s from his sister's room. He stands outside her door and  listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Did you throw up all over some girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks up the hall and sees his mother in her room,  sitting on the edge of her bed, smoking. He approaches an stands in her doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were throwing bottles at the  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon says nothing. He looks down at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to Fay's  room) She's got some ex-con in there she  met at the bar. Tattoos all over  himself and a big red bloated nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you take your pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she says nothing. She smokes and looks away. Simon steps into the bathroom and gets her medication. He runs a glass of water and brings it in to her. She swallows the pills and washes them back with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to tell her to be quiet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks away, unconcerned and cynical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use? She might as well  get it while she can. She's not always  gunna have the ass she has now, you  know. That's just how life is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws the blanket over herself and turns off the lig Simon stands there in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon comes downstairs into the quiet, dark kitchen and s at the table. He listens to the traffic on the highway an stares off into space. Finally, he takes the notebook Hen gave him from his pocket and places it before him. But th he just gazes off into the dim living-room and scratches head. Returning his attention to the notebook, he digs do into his pocket and retrieves his short stub of pencil. He opens the notebook and carefully flattens back the cov Lifting the pencil, he pauses and stares at the blank pag Then, after more intense hesitation, he brings the pencil dull tip to the very top left edge of the page and begins writing in a slow, laborious hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. Henry barges in the kitchen door with two containers of c and some jelly donuts. Simon jumps up from where he sits  asleep over his notebook at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Simon! Glorious day,  huh? Here, have a donut. Can you  lend me twenty dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon rubs the sleep from his eyes, blinks, disoriented a reaches for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Where's the library in the  scruffy little burgh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him cash) Down the highway about a mile and a  half and then make a left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent! I'm polishing up the final  chapters of my 'Confession' and I  need a reasonably well-stocked  reference section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts up Simon's notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon hesitates, shyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought. Um. I was. I wanted to.  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives up, sighs and gazes at the floor. Henry flips th the book, impressed. It is full from cover to cover, ever page dense with Simon's cryptic scrawl. Henry frowns,  intrigued. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks up, terrified. But his friend puts him at eas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll correct the spelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that day. Simon finds a number of volumes of the classics while cru garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening. Simon sits with his evening beer and his new collection o soiled classics. He cracks open a volume of Shakespeare a tries to read. It's an obvious struggle. He puts it aside and lifts up Wordsworth, studying its cover and the textu of the pages. A page flutters away and he climbs down to edge of a greasy puddle to retrieve it. It's now wet and  torn, so he flattens it out on the concrete and tries to it back into the book. He reads a little, furrowing his brow, then drinks. He bi his lip and tries again. He sits back, exhausted and thinks. He hears a twig snap looks back over his shoulder to see... Amy throws a bottle at his head. Smash!!!! He falls to the ground, blood streaming down hi neck. Warren runs over and grabs him by the shirt, lifting him of the puddle and smacking him in the head. Amy runs forward and waits with a rolled-up newspaper whi she sets aflame with her lighter. Warren punches Simon in the stomach and throws him to the ground, then unzips his fly and pisses on him. Amy watches, giggling excitedly, waving the flaming torch Simon crawls away and grabs hold of an old section of fen while Warren zips up and grabs the fire from Amy. Simon pulls himself to his knees, rests his face against rusted fence and gasps for breath. Warren waves the flami torch in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly, unheard) One of you is gunna lose an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy comes nearer with a can of gasoline. Simon pulls hims to his feet as she splashes him with fuel. Warren is wavi the torch deliriously above his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) One of you is gunna lose an eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren stops. Amy steps back and lowers the gas can. Simon turns with effort to face them, adjusts his glasses and continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of you. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren watches him blankly, then is burned by the torch w is too hot to handle. He drops it. Amy giggles, then stops, excited, but confused. Simon grips the rusted chainlink so that it cuts into his hands and stares straight at Warren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can set me on fire. But one of  you is gunna have an eye torn out of  your head. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren is transfixed. He shivers and looks at Amy, who st back, scared, and puts down the gas can. She turns and wa away. Warren looks back at Simon, troubled. He hangs there still, glaring at him. Further away, Warren rejoins Amy and stares at his hands. Amy looks ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is at one of the tables, correcting the spelling in Simon's notebook, when he looks up and sees... Simon stumble in, beaten and bruised, dropping his classi to the floor. Henry and Mr Deng rush over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) Simon! Who did this to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gunna tear out their eyes. I  knew I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them. Like you said. I told  them. And I knew I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes out. Henry looks at Mr Deng.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should take him home. He smells  like a toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry nods, agreeing, then lifts Simon off the floor. Mr  Deng holds the door open as Henry carries his friend out  into the parking lot. Meanwhile, Gnoc gathers up the classics from the floor an places them beside Simon's notebook, where it still sits  open on the table. She looks at it, then reads. She lifts off the table and reads further, immediately and deeply  engrossed. Mr Deng watches as Henry departs with Simon, then comes b into the store and stops, startled, when he sees... Gnoc sitting there, staring off into space, the notebook  open in her hands before her, singing quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes later. Fay is in the bathroom helping Simon out of his clothes,  trying to clean his wounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Shit, Mom, we gotta get him to a  hospital!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up! Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is at the kitchen table with Mary. She watches him  suspiciously. He lets her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kinda thing has happened before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches him as he walks around the room, browsing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops and lifts a small framed photo of a soldier off piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violated somehow, she gets up and snatches it out of his  hands. She puts it in a drawer and cringes as Henry plays one note on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fixes her with a steady, knowing stare which causes he to gather the collar of her bathrobe up around her neck. steps back, exposed, when there's a knock at the door. Th look over to see... Mr Deng enter with the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods to Mary, then) Mr Fool, what is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry comes over, takes the notebook from him and shoves in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm sure. I corrected the  spelling myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made my daughter sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you know -- that's what  poetry does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she has never spoken in her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, back in the bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owww!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep still!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fed up) Fine! You do it, Simon! I don't care!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She storms out to the top of the stairs, cocks her hip an whines...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Simon's got a broken rib, his  shoulder's dislocated or something,  and he won't let me disinfect the  gash in his head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay, just take him to the hospital,  will ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stamping her foot) But he won't go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Simon Grim, you go to the hospital  with Fay right now, do hear me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon reaches out and slams the bathroom door. Fay looks from the bathroom door down the stairs to Mary. Mary, her nerves rattled, glances over at Mr Deng, who tu and leaves the house. Henry lights a fresh cigarette, loosens his tie and heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later. Henry throws open the door and enters. He steps over Simo who is on the floor, folded up against the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sits on the edge of the bathtub and takes the noteb from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell were you trying to do  when you wrote this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon just looks at him, not certain what he means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know you wrote it in a  kind of iambic pentameter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iambic what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scratches his chin and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, in my opinion, this is pretty  powerful stuff. Though your spelling  is Neanderthal, and your reasoning a  little naive, your instincts are  profound. But the whole thing needs  to be given a more cohesive shape.  It can be expanded. Followed through.  Unified. (smokes, then) You see what I'm getting at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon just stares at him, overwhelmed. Henry drops the  notebook on the floor and points at it with his cigarette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you willing to commit yourself  to this? To really work on it? To  give it its due? In the face of  adversity and discouragement? To  rise to the challenge you yourself  have set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon just blinks, looks away and wonders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't gimme that wonderstruck  'I'm-only-a-humble-garbage-man'  bullshit, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Of course it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon coughs and Henry leans back and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later. Fay cringes outside Simon's room as Henry goes about sett her brother's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. No. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move! Fuck. There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now shut up and lie back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this gunna hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, then leans back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gunna be alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon nods and stares at the ceiling. Henry hands him a t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Bite on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spots blood on it) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking) It's blood. From your head. Lie back.  Shove that in your mouth and hold on  to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon bites down on the towel and grips the edge of the b with his free hand. Henry sits on his legs and gently rai the broken arm. Outside the door, Fay bites her knuckles. Further down th hall, Mary listens from her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon nods. Henry grabs hold of the arm, swallows and bra himself. Simon waits, then Henry tugs the arm straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaagghhh!!!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay turns and runs down the stairs. Mary backs away into room and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Henry comes downstairs and stops, tired. Fay is sitting a the table with a bottle of gin and two glasses. She has d herself up a little and Henry likes what he sees. He look her over and she smiles. He sits. She pours. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, do you have, like, you know, a  girlfriend, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink again in silence. He lights her cigarette and  they watch each other closely. Finally, Fay leans on the  table and twirls a strand of her hair between her fingers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find me attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look young for my age, don't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playfully) How young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how... I mean, do I look more  like twenty, or... you know, thirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks and studies her. She presents her profile. Fina he leans back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay jumps up, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you geek, after a couple of  drinks plenty of people mistake me  for eighteen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs her bag and storms out of the house. Henry watc her go, then chuckles deviously and splashes himself anot drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next morning. A thirty-year-old cocktail waitress named Vicky walks up stops when she sees... Warren, sitting back against the side of World of Donuts, smoking a joint and thinking about his future. She sighs and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Warren, are you a registered  voter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bug off, Vicky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unruffled, she hands him a flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Saving America From Itself.' What  the fuck is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's everything you need to know  about the upcoming elections and  congressman Owen Feer and all the  really good things he wants to do  for our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tokes deeply, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to win back this country  for us Americans, Warren, and restore  some kind of cultural-moral standard  to our way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren looks over the flyer, then reconsiders Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time's your kid go off to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about I come over and visit you  later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky sighs, troubled. She adjusts her waitress uniform a looks mildly offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know, Warren. I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren gets up, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. I mean it. I'm trying to  change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky is hard-pressed. She wants to believe him, but know better. She thinks about it while... Henry passes by and approaches the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same time. Henry enters and takes Simon's notebook from his pocket. flips through a few pages and selects one in particular. He tears it out of the book and tapes it up beside the  register so customers can read it. He winks at Gnoc. She  smiles shyly and makes him a coffee. He takes it and move off to a table just as... Vicky enters. She starts accumulating groceries, placing  them on the counter one item at a time. Henry settles down and watches as... Vicky returns to the counter with a bottle of orange juic and notices the poem. She reads, holding the orange juice out to her side. Gnoc starts to ring up the other purchases as her father  comes up behind her, busying himself with an inventory of the cigarettes. Vicky's lip starts to tremble as she reads, a horrified  expression clouding her face. Finally... Smash!!!! She drops the bottle of orange juice and stands back. Mr Deng and Gnoc jump back, alarmed. Henry tilts his head and pays close attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming at Mr Deng) How dare you put something like this  up where anyone can see it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deng looks from her to the poem and then over at Henry Henry urges the man to stand up for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) It's poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pornography! The product of a  diseased mind! You oughta be ashamed  of yourself, Mr Deng!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It made Gnoc sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses, confused) It's disgusting! There oughta be a  law or something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs her things and leaves. Mr Deng holds his head a looks over at Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking) There's no accounting for taste, is  there, Mr Deng?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Deng has no idea. He sits, worried, as Gnoc comes out  from behind the counter and begins mopping up the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Henry is at the kitchen table with Simon, working on the  poem. Simon is bandaged up, his arm in a sling, black eye etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Simon, there are three kinds of  there. There's 'There'. T-H-E-R-E.  There are the donuts. Then there's T- H-E-I-R; which is the possessive. It  is their donut. Then, finally, there's  'they're'. T-H-E-Y-'-R-E. A  contraction, meaning they are. They're  the donut people. Get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry lifts up one of Simon's newly acquired classics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look, if you're gunna read  Wordsworth you've gotta get a more  up-to-date edition. This odoriferous  tome you're so attached to doesn't  even have all fourteen books of the  Prelude. And you need notes.  Commentary. I'll go to the library  and find you the best edition they  have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, but that's OK. I'll stop  there on my way back from work. Well,  yes, maybe not today, but, you know,  tomorrow, probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need time to write, Simon. To  study. To reflect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I like my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have to make sacrifices. A  vocation like ours, Simon, is not a  nine to five thing. You can't put a  fence around a man's soul. We think  and feel where and when we can think  and feel. We are the servants of our  muse and we toil where she commands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks past him and Henry follows his gaze to find.. Mary standing at the foot of the stairs, listening to the She says nothing. She looks Henry up and down, then shake her head disdainfully and grunts. She throws herself on t couch and turns on the TV, casting acid glances over at t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Henry and Simon come outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's clinically depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and what's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking, then) I guess it means it's not her fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry wanders out to the road, checking his wallet, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) You ever think of leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To go where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out there. You know, into the world.  Where ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks off, thinks it over and slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reciting) 'Opportunity will step away and make  room for a man to pass it by.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that from your book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I found it in a fortune cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the tiny piece of crumpled advice out from one o his pockets and shows it to Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I read your confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. Soon. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it almost finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puffing himself up) Well, you know, Simon, a piece of  work like this, it's... A vocation  like ours... You can't put a fence  around a man's soul. What I'm trying  to achieve, it's... Well, it takes a  lifetime really. It's a life's work. (looking around) But soon. Don't worry. I'd appreciate  your feedback. I gotta go. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries away around the corner. Simon walks back to th house and stops when he sees... A plain-clothes policeman, Officer BuГ±uel, drive up and before the house. Simon spies as the man gets out of his car and knocks on  Henry's door. He, of course, gets no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that day. Simon works on his poem at the kitchen table while Fay fl through a magazine and watches TV. Mary, lying on the cou in her bathrobe, watches her own TV. The cacophony is augmented by the rattling dishwasher and the trucks rumbling by on the highway outside. Mary looks over at her son, suspicious, and leans off the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing there, Simon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carefully finishes writing a word, then looks up and  pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at Fay, who looks up from her magazine and  considers her brother. Then they break out laughing. Simon looks on. They laugh and laugh and laugh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Simon is bent over his notebook, consulting a dictionary, hard at work. Amy and three kids are grouped around the register, readi the page Henry taped up earlier. As they read, Amy glance anxiously back at Simon. They finish reading and stand back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? It ain't so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Amy, of Simon) That him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy nods 'Yes', then leads them towards Simon. Simon scribbles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Pardon me, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, sees her, panics and slides away on the seat Amy looks down and bites her lip, contrite. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhm. Look, ah... I'm the editor of  the high school newspaper now and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the editors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the editors, and we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... wanted to know if we could print  your poem in this month's issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks around at them all, threatened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think it's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pat) Who cares what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-known drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Simon) Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon fumbles with his pencil, ill at ease and self-consc Then, to get rid of them, he nods his consent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening. Fay comes downstairs in only a towel and wet hair. She  switches on the TV and looks for cigarettes. She finds Ma pills on the table and remembers to ask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma, you take your medication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is lying on the couch. She drags her eyes from the T and glances lazily at Fay, then back to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits at the kitchen table and lifts her magazine. Henry shows up at the kitchen door with a pile of library books. His eyes brighten when he sees... Fay sitting there wearing only her towel. He knocks. She  looks back over her shoulder and sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Fay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disdainfully) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got these books for Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, leave 'em there on the counter,  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes in and stacks the books near the sink. Fay prete to ignore him, but rakes her fingers through her wet hair anyway, to show more shoulder. This is not lost on Henry, who tarries and leans back aga the counter, salivating. Fay flips through her magazine and Henry steps closer and leans against the fridge. She casts a bored glance in his direction, then returns h attention to the TV. She senses him step aside and follow his movements without turning. Suddenly his hand appears  from behind her and gently strokes her hair. She freezes, waits, wonders... He leans his face down beside her. She looks at him. He l at her, then down to... Her bare legs crossed before her on the kitchen chair. Hi hand moves down and slides itself deep in between her thi Her mouth drops open. He looks back up at her. He grins. Fay jumps up and away, breathlessly clutching the towel a herself. Henry casts a glance over her body, throws his hair back of his face and shivers with lust. Fay steps back and grabs hold of the staircase banister,  making an unconvincing gesture of injured pride. Henry comes closer and she steps backwards up the stairs. He stops, loosens his tie, holding her with his gaze. She readjusts her towel, throws back her wet hair, sighs  defiantly, then sashays into her room, leaving the door a Henry waits there at the foot of the stairs, reaches down grabs his crotch and repositions his hard-on. He takes a  step up the stairs, then stops. He looks over to the couc and sees... Mary, lying there, sedately amazed. He pauses, then grins. Mary blinks and smiles sleepily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same time. Simon sits back from his writing and rubs his neck. Putti down his pencil, he looks up and sees... Warren enter the store and grab a beer from the cooler. S Simon, he waves and approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Simon, you a registered voter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon hesitates, but then nods uncertainly. Warren hands a flyer. This year when you go to the polls, I want you t consider Congressman Owen Feer. He wants to restore Ameri to its position of unmatched wealth, power and opportunit to revitalize American civilization and lead the human ra to even greater levels of freedom, prosperity and securit He's a good man. He steps over to the register and pays for his beer. Mr D glares at him, distrustfully. Warren stops on his way out and snarls at the old man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immigrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Simon looks down and studies the flyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same time. Fay lies across her bed in her towel, holding a pose and  glancing anxiously back at the door. Finally, losing her  patience, she gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and looks out into the hall. He's not there. She steps out into the hall and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. She comes to the top of the stairs and hears fai activity from down below. She proceeds downstairs. She sees no one in the kitchen, then looks in the living- room and stops. She goes white, her mouth falling open in horror. Henry and Mary are screwing one another on the couch. Slo impassioned, brute sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Mommy!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall away from each other in terror and fatigue. Mar clutches wildly at her bathrobe as Henry falls over the c table, stumbles to his feet and pulls up his trousers. Fay is crushed. She breaks out in tears and runs upstairs Henry catches his breath and starts after her, but stops, uncertain and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is asleep with his head down on the table. He wakes finally and sees... Henry sitting across from him, gripping a beer and readin the poem. He finishes, shuts the book and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. I know a man. He's a big  shot in the publishing business.  Angus James. Smart, adventurous and  tons of integrity. When this thing  is ready, I'll recommend he reads  it. He'll respect my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon takes this in, then looks down at his hands and pro carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man was here today looking for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alert) What man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He drove by the house  a few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry throws his eyes heavenward and pulls his hair. Jump to his feet, he paces maniacally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they torment me like this?  Why? They're like a bunch of fucking  mosquitoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A customer a few tables away gets nervous and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they want from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to suffocate me, Simon!  They wanna extinguish me like a flame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kid named Tim, sitting at another table, turns aroun and asks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're afraid, that's why! They're  afraid of what I might do! What I  might say! Think! They're afraid of  my ideas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, then returns and sits beside Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I are alike in this way,  Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're outsiders. We think and feel  too much and too deeply. And the  world can't handle that. Our mere  existence is a threat to its illusion  of security. Sure, they'll name a  wing of a new library after us when  we're dead! But now... Now, when  we're alive... Now, they wanna burn  us at the stake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, burps, then slams down the can. He glances ove at Tim who is still looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim hesitates, but then obeys. He gets up and leaves. Hen returns to Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For example, I made love to your  mother about half an hour ago and  now I'm beginning to think that maybe  it wasn't such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon blinks. Henry adds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to say, I think Fay may be  jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon is deeply confused. He looks ill. He stands and tak a few steps away, staring at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to think about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad move, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon stops and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at him) A poet has got to be able to think  about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon pauses, then comes closer to Henry and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I really a poet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry jumps up, strides around the store and speaks at th top of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you are! A great poet! But  you need experience. You need to do  something to be ashamed of every  once in a while, for cryin' out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Let's go out! There's a den  of iniquity right across the street!  You got any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides out of the store. Simon stands there, stunned and looks at Mr Deng as the o man wipes off the table with a wet rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Henry is dancing wildly on the bar with two sloppy-drunk  topless dancers. The place is rocking and the crowd cheer them on. Simon sits perched on a stool, gripping the bar with whit knuckles and clutching a beer, looking on in terror as... Henry starts stripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Simon stumbles in and heads upstairs. But he stops, seein Mary, sitting on the top step, smoking. She looks guilty tense. So does Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man's a bad influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and storms into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon comes upstairs and stops outside his bedroom door w he sees... Fay, passed out drunk on her bed. Her clothes are half of and her lipstick smeared. She still grips a bottle of teq in her hand. Simon hesitates, but then goes in and removes her shoes. gets her out of her jacket and rolls her into the bed. Her bare limbs have their effect on Simon and he finds hi staring at her thigh. He reaches out and almost caresses her leg where her hike up skirt reveals the bottom of her behind. He catches him snaps his hand away and covers Fay with a blanket. He flees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon is alone in the room with his bed. The pale sheets beckon. He is flushed. He blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. He creeps down the stairs with an arm-load of books. Sitt at the table, he wrenches a nearby lamp into a more usefu position and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. Henry stumbles up the stoop carrying a laptop computer, i various accessories and a couple of coffees. He lets himself in and dumps the computer on the kitchen  counter. Simon is asleep on the couch, still in his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving him) Simon. Hey, Simon. (Simon wakes) Come on. I got ya some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry trudges back to the kitchen, where he whips out his red pen and immediately begins to correct Simon's poem. Simon rolls off the couch and makes his way to the table. Seeing the computer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a computer. You write on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Stops, drinks declares...

dialogues.text: They were not 'lost years'.

What shouts of outrage from the  offended populace, from the  sanctimonious purveyors of culture  and quality, the righteous defenders  of what ever inane and haphazard  notion of progress then in vogue. dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, like a mirror which reflects  only the inside of the person before  it, my 'Confession' will lovingly  render humanity's common monstrosity  in all of its lurid wide screen glory.

dialogues.text: He grabs a new beer and twists off its cap.

dialogues.text: Why should I blush or feel shame  before the common lot of humanity,  anyway, for a few banal and, again I  admit, inelegant transgressions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, sighs and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, really, I'm doing  civilization a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon sits back in awe. He waits a moment and thinks. Fin he stands and approaches the 'Confession'. He reaches out and drags his hand across the notebooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sits staring into the flames again. He pauses, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next day. Simon and Father Hawkes are deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are told not to judge. But to  forgive. Not to look into our  neighbor's eye to find the bad, but  to find the good. (pacing) Now this is difficult. I admit. (pause) But having a good friend is not always  easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon listens and carefully considers all the priest says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but... do you think Henry is...  dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Hawkes pauses, then comes closer and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs help. Our help. Yours  especially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best parts of himself come to  the surface when he's helping someone  learn. I've seen this. Let yourself  be taught. Show your appreciation  for his guidance. In this way, you  know, perhaps. Well. There's hope  for everyone. Even. Even Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay comes walking up through the parking lot with Simon's notebooks and a pile of typed papers. She's a wreck; tear stained face and a ball of tissues gripped in her hand li a weapon. She throws open the door to the World of Donuts and looks around. The place is crowded with teenagers hanging around like i was a cafГ© or student union. Fay sniffles tragically and falls on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gnoc, gimme a value pack of Kleenex,  will ya?

dialogues.text: Gnoc gets the Kleenex while Fay overhears two kids near  Simon's poem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The violence of the imagery reminds  me of early Clash, while the lyricism  of the verse recalls, for me, Walt  Whitman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have said Dickinson, maybe  even Eliot, and so on. But I agree  with the punk roots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay pays for her tissues and makes her way to the back of the store where she finds Simon with Henry, who is holdin forth to his friend and the small coterie of high school  students surrounding them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greats all say the same thing:  little. And what little there is to  be said is immense. Or, in other  words, follow your own genius to  where it leads without regard for  the apparent needs of the world at  large, which, in fact, has no needs  as such, but, rather, moments of  exhaustion in which it is incapable  of prejudice. (drinks) We can only hope to collide with  these moments of unselfconsciousness.  This divine fatigue... this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting) Push over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry takes the typed manuscript from her and continues..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I tried to make plain in Paris:  'Nous savons que nous avons chutГ©  parce que nous savons qui nous  sommes.' 'We know we have fallen  because we know who we are.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptically) When were you in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupted) That's beside the point. But did  they listen to me? Of course not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You alright, Fay?

dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) No, I'm not alright! Your poem brought  my period on a week and half early!  So just shut up. Everybody just shut  up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For is this not the best of all  possible worlds? Are not the evils  of this world necessary components  of a cosmos that could not exist  without them?

dialogues.text: Amy's girlfriend, Chris, leans forward studiously and ask

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, do you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smokes, shrugs) Unfortunately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting her head) Yeah, but when were you in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggravated) At. One. Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, can I have your autograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks from her to Henry. Henry winks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. But never let yourself be  flattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Henry) So what about this friend of yours,  Hot Shot? The publisher.

dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reminding him) Angus James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's not done yet.

dialogues.text: (to Simon) When's it gunna be done, Simon?

dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.text: Well, you oughta be home writing  instead of hanging out over here  with all your groupies.

dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not a groupie.

dialogues.text: Pardon me, swivel-hips. Is that your  PowerBook?

dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.text: (continues) The thing to do is to send parts of  it to different magazines and literary  journals first. That kinda thing.  You know. Substantiate it.

dialogues.text: Henry sips his beer and looks at her.

dialogues.text: Filth, child. A preoccupation with  excrement. Why?

dialogues.text: The next day. Fay is frying something on the stove, a cigarette hangs f her lip. A middle-aged woman with a press ID on her lapel appears at the kitchen door and taps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Edna Rodriguez and I write  the human interest column for the  Queens County Examiner and I was  just wondering if I could have a  word with Simon Grim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intrigued, Fay steps over to the door with her spatula. S looks Edna over, studies her ID, then steps away and scre upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Thank you.

dialogues.text: Fay comes back over near the door, waving her spatula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't talk to him for, you know,  too long or anything, 'cause he's  gotta, you know... he writes all  day. That's all he does. Can you  believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling again) Hey! Simon! Get down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon finally shuffles into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, this is Edna. She's from the  newspaper.

dialogues.text: (rapid fire) Simon, the Parents' Association at  the local high school are calling  your poem pornography. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon says nothing. He just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (punching him) Simon, answer the woman.

dialogues.text: Never said a word.

dialogues.text: He masturbated constantly.

dialogues.text: Had no friends.

dialogues.text: Till he met Henry.

dialogues.text: And that's when all the trouble really  started.

dialogues.text: Henry is shaving. Simon sits in the kitchen, sorting thro rejection letters...

dialogues.text: (reading) Dear Mr Grim, we here at the magazine  consider ourselves and the publication  open-minded and cutting edge and  have consistently printed the work  of the most brilliant and farseeing  young talent of the day. dialogues.text: (thinking) You can't argue with taste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About taste. You can't argue about  taste. God, Simon.

dialogues.text: Simon gives up and pushes the letters away, beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other twenty-five are almost as  bad. I don't know why I bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry drops his razor and stomps out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean you don't know why  you bother? You bother because you  know the poem is excellent!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you sit there, look me straight  in the eye, and tell me you don't  think this poem is great? That it is  not at once a work of great lyrical  beauty and ethical depth? That it is  not a genuine, highly individual,  and profound meditation on the miracle  of existence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon holds the stare, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you?

dialogues.text: Simon looks away, thinks a moment, then looks back at Hen

dialogues.text: No. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry? Can you recommend the poem to  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I think it's finished and,  for better or worse, it is book  length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might not be as easy as it seems.

dialogues.text: You said he respected your opinion.

dialogues.text: Henry puts down his razor and looks at Simon in the mirro

dialogues.text: Look, Simon, opinions come and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Simon looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest; my ideas, my writing,  they haven't always been received  well or even calmly. They're  upsetting. I'm a controversial man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks around the bathroom, gesticulating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, what I'm doing is too  radical. Too uncompromising. It'll  take time for people to see its value.  It's ahead of its time, perhaps, or  maybe just... (stops) A recommendation from me might do  you as much harm as it does good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon patiently absorbs all this, then walks through the  kitchen and looks across at the 'Confession' notebooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, why can't I read the  'Confession'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because certain work needs to be  experienced all at once in order for  one to appreciate the full force of  its character.

dialogues.text: Simon talks with Fay as she eats her lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, wake up! The guy's in a dream  world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's afraid that his reputation will  prevent people from giving my work  an honest chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His reputation as what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's kinda like in exile. Marginalized  on account of his ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's such a great big fat genius,  why doesn't he write books? Like you  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has. He's written a book. It's  almost completed. He's been working  on it for years. It's just not  published.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I bet. It's probably disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) It's a quite serious and difficult  piece of work, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. Soon. Certain work needs  to be experienced all at once in  order for one to appreciate the full  force of its character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, what ever. Listen, Simon,  forget Henry. Go straight up to this  Angus James character yourself and  make him read your poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

She gets off the couch and moves to the kitchen table, wh Fay's computer sits. She goes over and reaches up above t fridge, opening the cabinet containing Simon's notebooks. But then she stops, pauses, and looks behin her. Simon is standing in the kitchen. He has been deeply affe by her playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares him down a moment longer, then looks away and  closes the piano. She returns to the couch and switches o the TV. Simon comes closer. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was nice what you were playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was nice. But it was  unremarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon waits. Eventually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking right at him) Yes. It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up off the couch and goes upstairs. She slams he bedroom door and leaves Simon alone on the couch. He thin Then, he gets up and goes into the kitchen. He takes the typed manuscript of his poem from the cabine above the refrigerator and goes to the door. He pauses,  clutches the poem and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. She steps over to the cabinet and almost takes down Simon's notebook. But doesn't. She grabs her pills a is about to take them. But then she stops. dialogues.text: Moments later. Simon comes out of the elevator and enters the reception  area of James Midriff and Sutton Publishing. He walks  hesitantly up to the receptionist, a bright and spirited  young woman named Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'll take that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon steps back defensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you the messenger?

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you here to fix the plumbing?

dialogues.text: I'm here to see Mr. Angus James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a plumber. Or a messenger. I  was once a garbage man. But now I'm  a poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura steps back, cocks her head and removes her designer eye-wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same time. Angus is at a big table with two other men, Steve and Bar

dialogues.text: The book, as we know it, Angus, will  be a thing of the past within the  next few years. Novels, articles,  newspapers will all be downloaded on  to our personal computers anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're telling me to get out of  the publishing business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right-e-o.

dialogues.text: (returning) So, anyway, how is the digital  revolution going to help me sell  books?

dialogues.text: (sincerely) Because he's a very important man  and, well, you're not.

dialogues.text: I don't think people are going to  prefer reading books on television,  Steve.

dialogues.text: It'll be interactive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it'll be a direct connection to  all forms of media.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unprecedented transformation of  American social life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll all become better informed,  more literate, increasingly  productive, and... Well, and, like I  said, we have a number of charts...

dialogues.text: He's been denounced by his local  Board of Education.

dialogues.text: Hello, and why do you think I should  take valuable time out of my busy  schedule to read...

dialogues.text: He grabs the envelope and sees no title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.text: Simon is stumped. He looks over at Laura, who purses her  lips and tilts her head. He twists a button on his shirt, thinking, then returns to Angus.

dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.text: (to Laura) Are you hearing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's adorable.

dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to waste your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you wouldn't and I appreciate  you being so straightforward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you can take straightforward  criticism?

dialogues.text: Simon looks over at Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say 'Yes'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him a coffee, Laura.

dialogues.text: Have a seat, Mr Grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold my calls for the next half hour.

dialogues.text: (off) Angus, listen to me!

dialogues.text: Henry paces back and forth. With the fingers of one hand  pressed against his forehead and his eyes closed tight in concentration, he dictates to Amy, who is sitting at a ta with her laptop computer, typing his every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the infinite amplitude of his  love, God wants to create the largest  number of best elements that can  exist together in one cosmos... OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy types away, fascinated by Henry's intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an instantaneous calculation made  in eternity, God computes the best  possible world and creates it. Fine.  This 'decision' by God is uncontingent  and eternal rather than temporally  or ontologically sequential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stops, zeroing in on his point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you spell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, do something.

dialogues.text: Simon walks down the aisle to see to Amy. The guests watch and wait. As Simon reaches her, Amy looks away from the altar and s him the fax scroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies the fax and recognizes his poem. He grows  concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?
