dialogues.text: It's all over the Internet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon looks up the aisle at... Fay and Henry. They look away, caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're even talking about it on the  TV news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused, Simon starts for the door, shoving the fax in h pocket. Fay steps down from the altar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy hurries along beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a guy from the radio station  over at World of Donuts and a story  in the newspaper about some kids  burning down a school near Boston!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that evening. The whole neighborhood is celebrating Fay's wedding. The  music is loud. The people are drunk. The place is a shamb A big dance number is playing. Amidst all the festivities though, Simon and BuГ±uel have the small TV propped up on of the fridge, following the evening news...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) It all started right here in Queens,  Jim, at World of Donuts about one  year ago today, when local garbage  man, Simon Grim, put pencil to paper  and began to compose what many have  come to regard as vicious, antisocial  and pornographic poetry -- 112 lines  of unrhymed free meter verse which  would one day serve to spark the  flames of controversy across the  nation and -- indeed -- the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay leads the neighbors in the dance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) This is outrageous! Measures must be  taken. Have we debased our culture  to such an extent that a garbage man  with a head full of sick ideas is  legitimately referred to as a poet,  and where the filth he spews can be  accessed by any child old enough to  turn on a computer? Is this what we  have come to? Not the transmission  of our highest ideals, but a cynical,  atheistic delirium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Fay dance, surrounded by the dancing neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) Poetry of this kind, and this poem  in particular, is, I think, a worthy  form of desperation; a digression on  the extremes of human experience; of  solitude, of community. It is perhaps  alarming, even upsetting to some --  myself included -- but it must be  allowed to exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry throws an arm around Warren, who stands looking dej in the doorway, and raises his glass to the happiness in room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) Meanwhile, in Rome today, the Pope  issued a message of hope for believers  in their fight against what he termed  the godless and lost. He did not  mention Simon Grim by name, but  offered a prayer for the young whom  he described as sadly in need of  faith and not the illusion of  conviction offered by rock music,  drugs and contemporary poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is switched off. It's later now. People are passed out on the kitchen floor and various neighbors are sittin around the table. Fay steps back from the TV, drains a gl of beer and wipes her mouth on the sleeve of her wedding  gown. She hugs Simon, who is deeply unsettled by the news his growing infamy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Simon, I mean, like, you're a  total fucking rock star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge crowd of kids are pressed up against the doors, tr to get a peek at their hero, Simon Grim. Angus comes away from the window. He stands and regards S who is sitting at a table tearing a napkin to shreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm willing to negotiate, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've had other offers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes. But.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why have you reconsidered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think your writing will be  tremendously successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's growing on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made you change your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the fans outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other people's responses. I don't  live in a vacuum, you know. Two months  ago I didn't have the proof of your  poem's appeal. Now I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon thinks this over, but says nothing. Angus comes ove and lays his hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider my offer carefully. Get  some professional advice. I'll call  you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Angus emerges and has to fight his way through the throng excited adolescents. He reaches his limo and gets in. But pauses before closing the door and considers the crowd. Simon emerges from the store and kids begin screaming and shouting for autographs. Angus shakes his head, impressed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon consults Father Hawkes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were the terms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand in cash up front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royalties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seventy/thirty split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that could be better. But it  is a hundred thousand dollars up  front. Guaranteed money. You could  use that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's a good deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I should take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Try to get him up to a hundred  and fifty thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening. Henry stalks along, all fired up. Simon tries his best to keep up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've let myself down, Simon! I've  let myself be caught in the bloody  maw of banal necessity! How did I  get here? How did this happen to me?  I'm going to be somebody's father! I  need time to think. To write. Time  to finish my 'Confession'! I can't  work for a living! It's impossible!  I tried once. My genius will be wasted  trying to make ends meet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He collapses extravagantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how great men topple, Simon.  Their hearts are in the right place  too much of the time! They get  sidetracked! Distracted. Oh! How  could I have been so careless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, please, let me read the  'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not now. It's not done. I'm all  washed up. I'm finished!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus James is convinced my poem is  going to make him incredibly wealthy.  He'll read your book and seriously  consider publishing it. If I ask him  to. I'm certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry glances back at his friend, digesting this. He thin it over, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having finally got through to him, Simon comes forward,  anxious to help Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll insist he publish the  'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces back and forth, thrusting out his chest, for the first time in his life displaying something like pride or arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adds) Or I won't let him publish my poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry sits there watching Simon, impressed with this evid of increased self-esteem. He realizes the profundity of t gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that? You'd do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon stares off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is moved. He stands and comes forward. He grabs his friend by the shoulders and turns him around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing) I owe you everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry steps away, considering, then looks back at Simon a extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon smiles. Henry smiles. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon enters, comes forward into the room and pauses, loo off at... The stack of twelve books that comprise the 'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stands outside, watching his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon lifts the first volume, opens it and begins reading He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry paces, drinking and smoking nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon strides the length of the living room, reading. He  stops, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon reads in front of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BuГ±uel, Hawkes and Mr Deng sleep sitting up as Henry tal to himself. Fay leans out the back door and interrupts hi He looks at her, but says nothing. She sighs and goes bac inside: turning off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. Simon sits wearily reading the final page of volume twelv as the morning sun streaks into the room. Finally, he fin and slowly closes the book. He stands and crosses the roo Leaning against the wall, he removes his glasses and rubs his aching eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon steps out of Henry's apartment and sees Henry aslee on the back stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon stares into a glass of water. Fay sits ten feet awa waiting. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'Confession' lies on the big desk. Angus' hand comes  down upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've read this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want me to consider publishing  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As part of our deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, this book, it's... It's really  quite bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you said about my poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angus pauses and figures. He changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm offering you a very real  expression of my faith in your  writing. Two hundred thousand dollars  and a sixty/forty split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But just exactly what is the nature  of your faith in my writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Simon, you don't require my  admiration. You require my experience  as a publisher. And that experience  leads me to believe your poem will  make more money than any book of  poetry ever published. In history.  Virtually make you a household name  within two years. You'll never have  to work on a garbage truck again, I  assure you. Or do anything else for  that matter. Whereas this 'Confession'  by Henry Fool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is at a loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most I can say for this is...  The man is a scoundrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taught me everything I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He encouraged all that was  expressive in you to become manifest.  He inspired you to act. He influenced  your perception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon waits a while, staring at his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about if my advance is only a  hundred thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about money, Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could split the royalties  seventy/thirty.

dialogues.text: I will not publish Henry Fool's  'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon sits and lets this sink in. Angus waits, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign the contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon continues looking out at the city. Angus waits, but there is no response. Finally, Simon turns, pauses and sl crosses the room. He sits at the table and looks down at the contract. He signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay is in labor. Henry helps her into her coat as they ru for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Henry runs into the store and stands there, panicked, loo at Hawkes, BuГ±uel and Mr Deng. Gnoc runs out to get Fay.

dialogues.text: Henry and Gnoc load Fay into the van. The van pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry drives recklessly. Fay rolls around in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay is in a wheelchair being rushed down the hall. She is gripping Henry's hand as he runs along beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fay gasps and sweats as the Doctor and Nurse prepare her. She is scared. She looks over at... Henry, looking in through the window. He looks scared too Fay is sedated by gas. Henry is taken away by the Nurse. Fay stares up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is asleep on a row of waiting-room chairs, exhauste Simon comes running up the hall and finds him. It's late no one is around. He sits down beside Henry and shakes hi Henry wakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon? You're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up and Simon sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughs) It's a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Fay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon sits back, relieved. Then he remembers the rain-soa shopping bag he has with him. He pulls out a couple of ca of beer and hands one to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around, seasoned conspirators and make sure the coast is clear. Then they pop open the beers and toast. They drink. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon pauses, scared, then gets up and crosses the room. looks out of the window and gathers his strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Henry, Angus James didn't  like your 'Confession'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry looks at Simon blankly, then blinks and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. I see. Well, what now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he suggest changes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Simon comes back and sits again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, after all, there are things  I can do to make it more accessible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accessible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can soften up some of the language  and make it read easier. Take out  some of the more intratextual  references and popularize the  underlying Sturm und Drang, so to  speak. I can change its mode. Make  it more of a conventional novel  instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon just stares at him blankly, then sighs and shakes h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, Simon, don't be such a purist! I  appreciate your protectiveness, but  the integrity of the work gives it a  durability that can sustain such  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon comes over and lays his hand on Henry's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Really, Henry. Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying; that it doesn't  merit revision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying... Angus James didn't  like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps away and sits. Henry pauses, then approaches and leans down over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did you tell him what you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I think doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it does. You've got to use your  influence with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave it to him to read and he hated  it. What more can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can refuse to let him publish  your poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was before I read your book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hit hard) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at him) I signed the contract, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry stands there a moment longer, then lowers himself i the nearest seat, weakened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Henry, what did you expect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know. Honesty, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly) Look, if I had told you, when at  first I read it, that I thought it  was no good, what would you have  done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have respected your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And insisted that there's no  accounting for taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon's words catch in his throat. He turns away, frustra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I didn't bring it to  Angus because I thought it was good.  I brought it to Angus because you're  my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staggered) Oh how perfectly enormous of you,  Simon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes) Look, Henry, I did it! I wrote. I  wrote poetry because you told me to!  I worked! I worked while you sat  back and comfortably dismissed the  outside world as too shallow, stupid  and mean to appreciate your ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that such a priority? Is that  some sort of measure of a man's worth?  To drag what's best in him out into  the street so every average slob  with some pretense to taste can poke  it with a stick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits, tired) Maybe. Maybe it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry just stares at him, stands, then turns on his heel waves him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be pretty impressed with  yourself, huh? The all too obviously  talented new man, the important new  voice, the early clue to a new  direction, or whatever, etc., etc.,  etc! A popular new trend conveniently  packaged for the distracted young  herd! You want to be liked more than  you know, Simon Grim! You'd be nowhere  without me and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon hangs his head, destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is scared all of a sudden. But he puts on a defiant exterior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's time you left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands, drinks and walks over to the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you for what you were in the  beginning, Simon. I hold no grudge  and I'm certain you will, in time,  leave some serious and small dent in  this world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) The world is full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry take advantage of Simon's disillusionment and puts a big show of secure wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is full of shit. It's true.  And you have to walk through it.  That's your part. I'm sorry. But  you're no good at it. Perhaps I'm  not. Perhaps I wasn't made to walk  through shit. Go on now. Leave. Do  what you're good at. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon sits there a moment, numb with grief. Henry, red in the face, stares at the floor. Suddenly, Simon stands and walks out. Henry looks up and watches him go. He can hard believe it. He almost raises his voice and apologizes, bu can't. He lowers his head again and covers his face with hands, listening to Simon's footsteps receding through th halls. Simon walks on, away from us, down the hospital corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven years later. Fay bangs out of the kitchen door with her seven-year-old son Ned. Frazzled and overworked, she grips a loaded laun basket to her side as she sits Ned down on the curb and p at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid sits still, obviously guilty of some unspeakable  mischief, as Fay storms back into the house. He looks aro bored, then brightens up when he sees... Henry, coming up the street, hanging from the back of a  garbage truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
